questions.text: A post-operative patient who is immobilized develops sudden onset severe calf pain. What is the next investigation to be done? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Duplex USG

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The correct answer is duplex ultrasound (USG). The clinical picture suggests deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is a common complication in immobilized, post-operative patients.
  • • Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for diagnosing DVT as it combines traditional ultrasound and Doppler ultrasound to visualize blood flow and identify any thrombus in the veins.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. CT angiography: This is primarily used for pulmonary embolism, not for initial evaluation of suspected DVT.
  • • Option A. CT angiography:
  • • Option C. X-ray: This is not useful for diagnosing DVT, as it does not provide information about the veins or blood flow.
  • • Option C. X-ray:
  • • Option D. MRI: While MRI can visualize DVT, it is not the first-line investigation due to higher cost, longer procedure time, and less availability compared to duplex ultrasound.
  • • Option D. MRI:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For post-operative, immobilized patients with sudden onset severe calf pain, suggesting DVT, the next investigation should be a duplex ultrasound, which effectively visualizes the veins and assesses blood flow to confirm the diagnosis. ​

questions.text: Which nutritional deficiency is commonly associated with a chronic alcoholic presenting with a pruritic eczematous rash on the neck and dorsum of hands? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Niacin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Chronic alcoholism often leads to poor dietary intake, resulting in various nutritional deficiencies.
  • • One of the most significant deficiencies in chronic alcoholics is niacin (vitamin B3). Niacin deficiency leads to a condition called pellagra, which is characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.
  • • The dermatitis in pellagra is specifically photodermatitis, meaning it occurs in areas exposed to sunlight, such as the neck and dorsum of the hands. The rash is pruritic and eczematous, commonly presenting as Casal's necklace around the neck and gauntlet sign on the hands.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Riboflavin: Deficiency in riboflavin (vitamin B2) typically leads to symptoms such as cheilosis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis but does not cause the characteristic dermatitis seen in niacin deficiency.
  • • Option B. Riboflavin:
  • • Option C. Folic acid: Folic acid deficiency often presents with megaloblastic anemia and glossitis, not with the dermatological symptoms described in the question.
  • • Option C. Folic acid:
  • • Option D. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, primarily affecting the cardiovascular and nervous systems, rather than causing the dermatological symptoms seen with niacin deficiency.
  • • Option D. Thiamine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, commonly seen in chronic alcoholics, leads to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. The dermatitis is photodermatitis, presenting with a pruritic eczematous rash on sun-exposed areas like the neck and dorsum of the hands. ​

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is undergoing evaluation for successive recurrent pregnancy losses. On ultrasound, a Mullerian anomaly is suspected. What is the BEST way to confirm this? (NEET PF 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy:
  • • Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy:
  • • Hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy is considered the best invasive method to confirm the diagnosis of Mullerian anomalies. This approach allows direct visualization of both the internal and external contours of the uterus. During the procedure, hysteroscopy can evaluate the endometrial cavity, while laparoscopy can assess the external uterine surface and other pelvic structures. This combination not only confirms the diagnosis but also allows for simultaneous corrective surgery, if necessary (e.g., resecting a uterine septum).
  • • Hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy is considered the best invasive method to confirm the diagnosis of Mullerian anomalies. This approach allows direct visualization of both the internal and external contours of the uterus.
  • • During the procedure, hysteroscopy can evaluate the endometrial cavity, while laparoscopy can assess the external uterine surface and other pelvic structures.
  • • This combination not only confirms the diagnosis but also allows for simultaneous corrective surgery, if necessary (e.g., resecting a uterine septum).
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Hysterosalpingography : Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a useful imaging technique for evaluating the shape and patency of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. However, it may not provide detailed information about the external contour of the uterus or distinguish between certain types of Mullerian anomalies.
  • • Option A. Hysterosalpingography
  • • Option C. Laparoscopy : While laparoscopy alone can provide information about the external structure of the uterus and other pelvic organs, it does not allow for direct visualization of the endometrial cavity. Combining it with hysteroscopy gives a more comprehensive assessment.
  • • Option C. Laparoscopy
  • • Option D. Transvaginal sonography : Transvaginal sonography (TVS) is a non-invasive imaging technique that can detect many uterine anomalies. However, it may not be as definitive as hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy, especially for complex anomalies.
  • • Option D. Transvaginal sonography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The best way to confirm a suspected Mullerian anomaly is through hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy, which allows for a comprehensive assessment and potential simultaneous treatment.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 32, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 32, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used for cancers can cause hand-foot syndrome? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Capecitabine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Capecitabine, a pyrimidine analog, is the cancer drug most commonly associated with causing hand-foot syndrome, characterized by redness, swelling, and pain in the hands and feet.

questions.text: Identify the image and it is associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.correct_answer: A. Casal necklace – vitamin B3 deficiency
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Casal necklace – vitamin B3 deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Casal necklace is a classic dermatological manifestation of pellagra, which is caused by Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient is a diagnosed case of depression. He is concerned about side effects of his medication and requests you to prescribe a drug least likely to cause sexual dysfunction. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Bupropion

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is caused by the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lecithin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RDS is a common condition in premature infants due to inadequate surfactant production, particularly the deficiency of lecithin. The educational objective is to understand the etiology of RDS and its association with surfactant components, specifically lecithin. This knowledge is crucial for healthcare professionals involved in the care of neonates, as RDS can have serious respiratory consequences in premature infants and requires appropriate management and support.

questions.text: During excision of ranula along with sublingual gland, which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lingual nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During the excision of a ranula and the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is the structure most likely to be injured due to its anatomical position relative to the sublingual gland. This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and its injury can result in significant sensory deficits.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for a benign tumor of the superficial parotid gland on FNAC? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Superficial parotidectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superficial parotidectomy is the preferred treatment for a benign tumors like pleomorphic adenoma, providing targeted removal of the entire superficial lobe.

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could be attributed to? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Years lost due to premature death

options.label: D
options.text: Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.correct_answer: B. Years lost due to premature death
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Years lost due to premature death

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL) is a measure that quantifies the impact of premature death on a population by calculating the number of years not lived by individuals who die before reaching a specified age. It highlights the significance of early mortality and its impact on society.
  • ➤ Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL)

questions.text: M3 incisional hernia refers to: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Umbilical

questions.text: All are normal physiological changes in pregnancy except? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: Mild ST changes in inferior leads

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pansystolic murmur

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • During pregnancy, there are several physiological changes in the cardiovascular system:
  • • Clinical Examination: Jugular venous distension and venous hum are commonly observed. Mammary soufflé: A continuous murmur can be heard at the 2nd to 4th intercostal spaces. Flow murmurs at the aortic or pulmonary areas. Increased and widely split S1 sound. S2 P component is increased, and S2 is split. The apex beat is shifted to the 4th intercostal space, 2.5 cm outside the mid-clavicular line. Electrocardiography: T wave inversion and bi-atrial enlargement. Various dysrhythmias, including atrial and ventricular premature contractions, are relatively frequent. Due to the diaphragm being elevated during advancing pregnancy, there is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads. Pregnancy does not alter voltage. Tricuspid regurgitation may be present. Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension and left ventricular mass.
  • • Clinical Examination: Jugular venous distension and venous hum are commonly observed. Mammary soufflé: A continuous murmur can be heard at the 2nd to 4th intercostal spaces. Flow murmurs at the aortic or pulmonary areas. Increased and widely split S1 sound. S2 P component is increased, and S2 is split. The apex beat is shifted to the 4th intercostal space, 2.5 cm outside the mid-clavicular line.
  • • Clinical Examination:
  • • Jugular venous distension and venous hum are commonly observed. Mammary soufflé: A continuous murmur can be heard at the 2nd to 4th intercostal spaces. Flow murmurs at the aortic or pulmonary areas. Increased and widely split S1 sound. S2 P component is increased, and S2 is split. The apex beat is shifted to the 4th intercostal space, 2.5 cm outside the mid-clavicular line.
  • • Jugular venous distension and venous hum are commonly observed.
  • • Mammary soufflé: A continuous murmur can be heard at the 2nd to 4th intercostal spaces.
  • • Flow murmurs at the aortic or pulmonary areas.
  • • Increased and widely split S1 sound.
  • • S2 P component is increased, and S2 is split.
  • • The apex beat is shifted to the 4th intercostal space, 2.5 cm outside the mid-clavicular line.
  • • Electrocardiography: T wave inversion and bi-atrial enlargement. Various dysrhythmias, including atrial and ventricular premature contractions, are relatively frequent. Due to the diaphragm being elevated during advancing pregnancy, there is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads. Pregnancy does not alter voltage. Tricuspid regurgitation may be present. Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension and left ventricular mass.
  • • Electrocardiography:
  • • T wave inversion and bi-atrial enlargement. Various dysrhythmias, including atrial and ventricular premature contractions, are relatively frequent. Due to the diaphragm being elevated during advancing pregnancy, there is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads. Pregnancy does not alter voltage. Tricuspid regurgitation may be present. Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension and left ventricular mass.
  • • T wave inversion and bi-atrial enlargement.
  • • Various dysrhythmias, including atrial and ventricular premature contractions, are relatively frequent.
  • • Due to the diaphragm being elevated during advancing pregnancy, there is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads.
  • • Pregnancy does not alter voltage.
  • • Tricuspid regurgitation may be present.
  • • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension and left ventricular mass.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Left axis deviation: This is a normal change due to the diaphragm being elevated during pregnancy, causing an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the ECG.
  • • Option A. Left axis deviation:
  • • Option B. Mild ST changes in inferior leads: These are normal and can be seen due to the changes in heart position and function during pregnancy.
  • • Option B. Mild ST changes in inferior leads:
  • • Option C. Atrial and ventricular premature contractions: These are relatively frequent and considered normal in pregnancy.
  • • Option C. Atrial and ventricular premature contractions:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diastolic and pansystolic murmurs in pregnancy are not normal and should be investigated further.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 178, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 178, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the otolaryngology clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in the right side of his face. Upon examination, the physician noted swelling in the parotid gland, which is located in the cheek area. The patient also reported that his symptoms worsened when he ate food, and he had lost his appetite due to the discomfort. The physician ordered an ultrasound imaging of the salivary glands, which revealed the presence of multiple hyper-echoic areas within the parotid gland. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sialolithiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sialolithiasis, characterized by the formation of calculi in the salivary glands, typically presents with pain and swelling, especially during meals. Ultrasound imaging can identify hyper-echoic areas representing the stones, helping in the diagnosis.
  • ➤ Sialolithiasis, characterized by the formation of calculi in the salivary glands, typically presents with pain and swelling, especially during meals.
  • ➤ Ultrasound imaging can identify hyper-echoic areas representing the stones, helping in the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse develops urethral discharge one week later as shown in the given image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)

Prompt diagnosis and treatment with appropriate antibiotics, such as a combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin, are crucial to prevent complications and limit the spread of this highly contagious infection.

questions.text: What is the inheritance pattern? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mitochondrial

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by maternal transmission of a trait to all offspring, with no paternal transmission, due to the exclusive inheritance of mitochondria from the mother's egg cell

questions.text: True about sirtuins are all except?

options.label: A
options.text: Increases insulin sensitivity and supports glucose metabolism

options.label: B
options.text: It is a histone deacetylase and it causes chromatin condensation

questions.correct_answer: D. It is stimulated by niacinamide
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It is stimulated by niacinamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Sirtuins are involved in improving insulin sensitivity, supporting glucose metabolism, causing chromatin condensation through histone deacetylation, and extending lifespan. However, they are not stimulated by niacinamide; instead, niacinamide inhibits their activity.

questions.text: What immunization coverage percentage is required by the WHO for the eradication of measles? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 96%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To eradicate measles, the WHO recommends an immunization coverage of 96% among children under the age of 1, emphasizing the need for near-universal coverage to achieve herd immunity and effectively control the disease.

questions.text: Select the correct sequence: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenylyl cyclase → cAMP → PKA

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The sequence involves the activation of a G protein-coupled receptor pathway. When a hormone binds to its receptor, the associated heterotrimeric G protein undergoes a conformational change. This change leads to the exchange of GDP for GTP on the G protein's alpha subunit, causing it to dissociate from the beta and gamma subunits.
  • • The activated GTP-bound alpha subunit then interacts with adenylyl cyclase, an enzyme located on the inner membrane of the cell. Adenylyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP). The newly formed cAMP acts as a secondary messenger that activates Protein Kinase A (PKA). PKA, in turn, phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to a cascade of cellular responses.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence in the G protein-coupled receptor pathway is: Adenylyl cyclase activates the conversion of ATP to cAMP, which then activates Protein Kinase A (PKA).

questions.text: A resident physician sustained a needlestick injury while collecting a blood sample from a patient with HIV. It has been decided to provide the physician with post-exposure prophylaxis. What would be the most suitable course of action among the options below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.correct_answer: B. Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir for 4 weeks
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lamivudine+ Tenofovir+ Dolutegravir for 4 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Diarrhoea by cholera toxin involves which receptors: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholera toxin, produced by Vibrio cholerae, causes diarrhea by binding to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. The binding of cholera toxin to GM1 facilitates its entry into the cells, where it exerts its toxic effects by activating adenylate cyclase and increasing intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP). Elevated cAMP levels lead to the secretion of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea characteristic of cholera.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 212
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 212

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about nephroblastoma? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)

options.label: C
options.text: Treatment is by chemotherapy and surgery

options.label: D
options.text: It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

questions.correct_answer: D. It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neuroblastoma is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children, not Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the causes of fall in diastolic blood pressure is correct? (INICET NOV 2024) Loss of sympathetic outflow in the lumbar region Antagonism of beta-1 adrenergic receptors Blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors Antagonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1 and 3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A fall in diastolic blood pressure primarily occurs due to vasodilation. Two mechanisms listed that cause vasodilation are:
  • • 1. Loss of sympathetic outflow in lumbar region : Sympathetic system causes vasoconstriction, so its loss leads to vasodilation
  • • 1. Loss of sympathetic outflow in lumbar region
  • • 3. Blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors : Alpha-1 receptors mediate vasoconstriction, so their blockade causes vasodilation
  • • 3. Blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • 2. Antagonism of beta-1 adrenergic receptors : Incorrect. Beta-1 blockade primarily affects heart rate and contractility, leading to decreased systolic blood pressure, not diastolic pressure.
  • • 2. Antagonism of beta-1 adrenergic receptors
  • • 4. Antagonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors : Incorrect. Beta-2 receptors mediate vasodilation, so their blockade would cause vasoconstriction and potentially increase diastolic pressure.
  • • 4. Antagonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diastolic blood pressure is primarily affected by vascular tone - vasodilation decreases it (through loss of sympathetic tone or alpha-1 blockade) while vasoconstriction increases it.

questions.text: A patient presented with an enlarged inguinal lymph node. Which one is the most likely primary cause?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Anal cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anal cancer is a primary malignancy associated with the enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes due to its anatomical and lymphatic relationship with the anal canal below the dentate line. Recognizing this link is crucial for correct diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: On the promontory, behind the tympanic membrane, there is a red mass. CT is given. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:

questions.text: What is the purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adolescents

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The HEADSS assessment is a structured psychosocial interview technique specifically designed to be used with adolescents . The purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation is to provide a comprehensive framework for obtaining a detailed history from adolescents. It covers several key areas, including:
  • • adolescents
  • • Home & Environment- Understanding the adolescent's living conditions, relationships with family members, and any issues at home. Education and Employment - Gathering information about the adolescent's school performance, educational aspirations, and employment status. Activities - Identifying the adolescent's involvement in extracurricular activities, hobbies, and how they spend their free time. Drugs - Assessing the use of drugs, alcohol, and tobacco, including experimentation and regular use. Sexuality - Discussing topics related to sexual activity, orientation, and practices to ensure safe and healthy sexual behaviors. Suicide /Depression - Screening for mood issues, depression, suicidal thoughts, or other mental health concerns.
  • • Home & Environment- Understanding the adolescent's living conditions, relationships with family members, and any issues at home.
  • • Home
  • • Education and Employment - Gathering information about the adolescent's school performance, educational aspirations, and employment status.
  • • Education and Employment
  • • Activities - Identifying the adolescent's involvement in extracurricular activities, hobbies, and how they spend their free time.
  • • Activities
  • • Drugs - Assessing the use of drugs, alcohol, and tobacco, including experimentation and regular use.
  • • Drugs
  • • Sexuality - Discussing topics related to sexual activity, orientation, and practices to ensure safe and healthy sexual behaviors.
  • • Sexuality
  • • Suicide /Depression - Screening for mood issues, depression, suicidal thoughts, or other mental health concerns.
  • • Suicide
  • • Now Extended to become – HEEADSS
  • • Now Extended to become – HEEADSS
  • • E – Eating and Exercise
  • • E – Eating and Exercise
  • • S - Safety
  • • S - Safety
  • • Educational objective : The HEADSS assessment helps healthcare providers establish rapport with adolescent patients, identify risk factors, and discuss sensitive issues in a non-judgmental, confidential manner. This can lead to better health outcomes by addressing potential problems early.
  • • Educational objective :

questions.text: What is the latest online software introduced by the government under the national tuberculosis elimination program (NTEP) to monitor patients with tuberculosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) NIKSHAY

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NIKSHAY - Monitoring TB patients.
  • ➤ NIKSHAY
  • ➤ TB
  • ➤ NIKUSTH - Monitoring leprosy patients.
  • ➤ NIKUSTH
  • ➤ leprosy
  • ➤ NISCHAY - Pregnancy test kit.
  • ➤ NISCHAY
  • ➤ E-DOTS - Virtual Directly Observed Therapy DOT.
  • ➤ E-DOTS

questions.text: A woman with Grave's disease was taking antithyroid medication throughout her pregnancy. The baby was born with aplasia cutis congenita. Which drug could have caused this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MMZ, Carbimazole associated with embryonopathy in first trimester
  • ➤ Graves in Pregnancy:
  • ➤ <16 weeks: PTU (MM teratogenic)
  • ➤ >16 weeks: MMI (PTU hepatotoxicity)
  • ➤ Lactation: MMI (RAIA avoided 4-6 weeks after cessation of breastfeeding as RAI is concentrated in breast tissue)

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Hyperthyroidism/Graves/Chap 384

questions.text: Vaccine kept at the lowest level inside an Ice lined refrigerator (ILR) at PHC: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ OPV is stored at the lowest level of the ILR due to its requirement for the coldest storage conditions, ranging from 2°C and even tolerating freezing conditions, ensuring vaccine potency and effectiveness.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with normal bone mineral density. X-ray is given below. Identify the diagnosis: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Scurvy

questions.text: Which of the following is not helpful for differentiating between necrosis and apoptosis? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key features to differentiate necrosis from apoptosis include the state of cell organelles (intact in apoptosis, disintegrated in necrosis), enzyme-mediated degradation (present in necrosis), and internal organelle disintegration with lipid changes (present in necrosis). Altered cell shape alone is not a useful parameter for differentiation.
